questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents with his wife, who reports that he has grown increasingly forgetful. She describes a number of instances during the past few years in which he seemed unable to complete tasks that were not previously problematic for him. Neither the patient nor his wife has noticed a change in mood or affect, and a depression screening performed in clinic is unremarkable. In addition to obtaining collateral history, performing a physical examination, and obtaining appropriate blood and urine tests, which one of the following additional diagnostic steps is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although cerebrospinal fluid levels of various tau-protein forms may correlate with Alzheimer disease, their measurement is not currently recommended in clinical practice for the evaluation of dementia. Their utility as a diagnostic tool and as progression biomarkers is currently being evaluated in ongoing research studies.

B) CORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is a common form of dementia in older adults. Although a definitive diagnosis requires histologic examination of brain tissue, probable diagnosis is typically substantiated by detailed medical history, clinical examination, neuropsychological examination of multiple cognitive domains, and exclusion of alternative causes of dementia (e.g., by measurement of serum thyroid-stimulating hormone and B12 levels). Details of patient history provided by family members are particularly important, as some patients may have poor insight regarding their symptoms.

Guidelines from the American Academy of Neurology state that structural neuroimaging of the brain with either a noncontrast head CT or MR scan is appropriate in the routine initial evaluation of patients with dementia. Neuroimaging can serve to rule out structural brain lesions (e.g., neoplasms, subdural hematomas) that can manifest initially with cognitive impairment. MRI is preferable to CT because it has higher resolution, allowing for better detection of atrophy, strokes (including lacunes), white-matter changes, and microhemorrhages.

Key learning point: In addition to cognitive assessment, the appropriate tests for a patient with features of dementia are evaluation of thyroid-stimulating hormone and serum B12, complete blood count, complete metabolic panel, structural brain imaging with MRI or CT, and, if the patient is at risk, testing for sexually transmitted infections (e.g., HIV, syphilis).

C) INCORRECT:

Although a detailed neuropsychological test can be helpful, the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory is generally not relevant in the initial evaluation of a patient’s cognitive problems.

D) INCORRECT:

Metabolic imaging, such as 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose-positron emission tomography (PET), is still under investigation as a diagnostic tool in dementia and would be an inferior choice to a different imaging modality in this setting.

E) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography is not considered a routine test for patients presenting with chronic, slowly progressive cognitive decline, especially in the absence of episodic fluctuations in cognition and function that would raise suspicion for seizures.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the office by her son because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 2 years. She misplaces keys and forgets her dog's name or her phone number. She used to go for a walk every morning but stopped one month ago after she got lost on her way back home. She has hypertension, coronary artery disease, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include aspirin, enalapril, carvedilol, and atorvastatin. She makes multiple errors while performing serial sevens. Her clock drawing is impaired and she draws 14 numbers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by the triad of urinary incontinence, gait instability, and memory loss (“wet, wobbly, and wacky”). Although this patient has significant memory loss, she lacks the other features of the triad, making this diagnosis less likely. Neuroimaging would show enlarged ventricles.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

B) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia is characterized by dementia with visual hallucinations and parkinsonism (e.g., tremor, rigidity). Although this patient has cognitive decline, she does not have the visual hallucinations or motor symptoms that are commonly seen in Lewy body dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia is characterized by early, selective degeneration of the frontal and temporal lobes. Frontal lobe degeneration results in behavioral and personality changes (e.g., apathy, compulsive eating, disinhibition), and temporal lobe degeneration causes memory loss. Although this patient has memory issues, she does not have any of the classic findings of frontal lobe degeneration. Neuroimaging in early stages would show selective atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes, not global atrophy.

D) INCORRECT:

Certain cognitive declines are expected with normal aging, such as slowing of cognitive processing speed and issues with memory retrieval. In dementia, however, cognitive deficits exceed those of normal aging and impair the actions of daily living. Since the patient's cognitive declines impair her daily life (i.e., navigate her neighborhood), they are pathologic and more severe than what would be expected with normal aging.

E) CORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of slowly progressive memory loss. This condition typically affects the temporal and parietal lobes first: Temporal lobe degeneration results in memory loss (misplaced keys) and language deficits, whereas parietal lobe degeneration results in spatial navigation problems (getting lost during walks outside).
questions.hint: An MRI scan of the brain would show generalized cerebral atrophy.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman with Alzheimer disease, seasonal allergies, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes has experienced a subacute decline in her cognitive function. According to her family members, she has become more confused, often forgets to take her medications, and has difficulty recognizing familiar people. The patient and her family noticed an improvement in her cognitive abilities when she started taking donepezil 5 mg daily one year ago. Her other medications are atenolol, apixaban, lisinopril, and metformin. An increase in seasonal allergies led to recent initiation of diphenhydramine. Which one of the following medication changes is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Changing the dose of donepezil is unlikely to improve the patient’s symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing atenolol is unlikely to improve cognitive performance in a patient who has a normal heart rate and blood pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing donepezil is unlikely to improve the patient’s symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with Alzheimer disease, a gradual decline in cognition is to be expected despite use of an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. However, a subacute decline usually indicates a superimposed disorder, most often an infection (e.g., of the urinary tract) or a medication effect.

Anticholinergic agents, such as diphenhydramine, are relatively contraindicated in older patients with Alzheimer disease, who already have a cholinergic deficit. Several medication classes — including sedative antihistamines, tricyclic antidepressants, bladder antispasmodics, and numerous over-the-counter medications — have anticholinergic effects. Patients with Alzheimer disease vary in their tolerance of these medications; factors affecting tolerance include the dose, the patient’s cognitive reserve, hepatic and renal function, and the number of other medications being used.

Key learning point: A subacute decline in neurocognitive performance in a patient with Alzheimer disease is most frequently attributable to an infection or a new medication.

E) INCORRECT:

Adding an antipsychotic medication, such as risperidone, is not recommended for patients with Alzheimer disease, because the drug may have serious adverse effects, including increased mortality risk.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the office by his daughter because of gradually progressive forgetfulness over the last year. He frequently forgets the names of his neighbors, whom he has known for 30 years. He recently had an episode of urinary incontinence. Last week, his neighbor found him wandering the parking lot of the grocery store. He appears healthy; BMI is 23 kg/m2. Mini-mental state examination score is 19/30. He has 5/5 strength in all extremities and his gait is steady. MRI scan of the brain shows narrowing of gyri and prominent cerebral sulci. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

AD is caused by the degeneration of cholinergic neurons, leading to decreased acetylcholine synthesis and impaired cholinergic transmission to the cortex. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine) are considered first-line treatment in patients with mild to moderate AD because they promote an increase of acetylcholine concentration on the synaptic gap and have been shown to improve cognition and the ability to perform everyday activities. In patients with moderate to severe disease (≤ 18/30 MMSE) and in those who show disease progression despite being treated with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, memantine can be added to the treatment regimen.

Key learning point: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors such as donepezil are first-line pharmacotherapy for mild to moderate Alzheimer disease to improve cognition and daily functioning.

B) INCORRECT:

Thiamine is used in the treatment of Wernicke encephalopathy, a syndrome seen in patients with poor nutrition, typically in association with alcohol use disorder. This patient does not have a history of excessive alcohol use, and his healthy appearance and BMI do not indicate possible malnutrition (although it cannot be ruled out entirely, especially in an older patient). Moreover, patients with Wernicke encephalopathy also present with gait dysfunction and oculomotor dysfunction, such as nystagmus, lateral rectus palsy, or conjugate gaze palsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Levodopa and carbidopa are used in the treatment of parkinsonian symptoms in dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB). This patient does present with dementia, but other typical features consistent with DLB, such as extrapyramidal motor symptoms or visual hallucinations, are absent.

D) INCORRECT:

An SSRI, such as sertraline, may be indicated for the treatment of depression in AD, but not for the treatment of AD itself. Although AD and other forms of dementia are often associated with neuropsychiatric symptoms, this patient does not have symptoms of depression, (e.g., loss of interest, sleep disturbance).

E) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is the drug of choice for idiopathic intracranial hypertension and might also be used to treat normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). While NPH manifests with dementia and urinary incontinence on MRI, this patient has no gait disturbance, which is characteristic of NPH. Moreover, NPH is not associated with sulcal enlargement.

A Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score of 19/30 indicates mild to moderate disease.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her daughter for evaluation of progressive memory decline over the past year. She misplaces items, forgets recent conversations, and occasionally becomes confused about the day of the week. Her family reports no major personality changes. She is independent for most daily activities but needs help with finances. Neurologic examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia is characterized by early fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism, none of which are present in the patient's clinical presentation. The focus on progressive memory decline with normal neurologic examination does not align with Lewy body dementia, which typically includes visual hallucinations and motor symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Vascular dementia often presents with a stepwise cognitive decline following cerebrovascular events, accompanied by focal neurologic deficits. The patient shows gradual memory decline without sudden changes or focal deficits, and there is no history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks, making vascular dementia unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal dementia usually presents with early changes in behavior, personality, or language, which are absent in this patient. The primary symptoms involve memory decline without behavioral or language changes. Additionally, frontotemporal dementia typically occurs at a younger age than 80 years.

D) CORRECT:

Alzheimer disease manifests with progressive memory decline, particularly affecting short-term memory, and is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. It typically presents with an insidious onset and gradual worsening of memory deficits, while other neurologic functions remain intact until later stages. The patient's symptoms, such as misplacing items and forgetting recent conversations, reflect neurodegeneration in the hippocampus and related regions, impairing memory consolidation. Neuropathologic findings include beta-amyloid plaques and tau neurofibrillary tangles, which disrupt neuronal communication. Additionally, difficulty with complex tasks, like managing finances, indicates declining executive function as the disease progresses.

Key learning point: Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly, characterized by progressive memory loss and cognitive decline.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman has one-year progressive memory decline and occasional disorientation. Which initial diagnostic test is most appropriate for suspected Alzheimer’s disease?

choices.text: Lumbar puncture for measurement of cerebrospinal fluid beta-amyloid and tau levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Genetic testing for presenilin mutations is relevant in early-onset familial Alzheimer's disease, typically presenting before age 65. The patient is 80 years old, suggesting late-onset sporadic Alzheimer's disease, where genetic testing is not indicated in the initial workup.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid beta-amyloid and tau levels provides supportive evidence for Alzheimer's disease but is not the initial test. It is reserved for ambiguous cases or when neuroimaging is inconclusive. Lumbar puncture is invasive and carries procedural risks, making it less desirable initially.

C) INCORRECT:

FDG-PET imaging evaluates cerebral glucose metabolism and can identify hypometabolism patterns in Alzheimer's disease. However, it is not the initial test of choice. It is used when structural imaging is inconclusive or in atypical presentations, as it is less readily available and more costly than MRI.

D) CORRECT:

MRI of the brain is the initial diagnostic test of choice for suspected Alzheimer's disease due to its ability to provide high-resolution images that reveal brain atrophy patterns, particularly in the medial temporal lobes and hippocampus. It is crucial for excluding other causes of cognitive decline, such as vascular lesions, tumors, or subdural hematomas. MRI also assesses ventricular enlargement and cortical atrophy, which are supportive findings in neurodegenerative conditions. As a noninvasive and widely available modality, MRI is central to the initial evaluation of patients with progressive cognitive impairment.

Key learning point: Brain imaging is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test in the evaluation of suspected Alzheimer's disease to rule out other causes of dementia and identify characteristic patterns of brain atrophy.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old woman is brought to the clinic by her son due to progressively worsening memory over two years. She has difficulty remembering recent events, struggles with daily tasks she once managed easily, and occasionally displays uncharacteristic irritability. She does not take any medications regularly. Neurological examination reveals no focal deficits. Laboratory studies, including complete blood count, electrolytes, and thyroid function, are unremarkable.
Which of the following findings is most likely responsible for her symptoms?

choices.text: Pick bodies composed of hyperphosphorylated tau in frontotemporal regions
Intracellular inclusion bodies composed of alpha-synuclein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pick bodies are associated with Pick disease, a form of frontotemporal dementia, which presents with early behavioral and language disturbances, often in younger individuals. This patient's primary issue is progressive memory loss, not the behavioral changes typical of frontotemporal dementia, making Pick bodies an unlikely cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Spongiform vacuolization is characteristic of prion diseases like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which present with rapid cognitive decline over weeks to months, often with myoclonus. The patient's gradual memory decline over two years and stable neurological examination are inconsistent with prion disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-synuclein accumulation forms Lewy bodies, associated with Parkinson disease and dementia with Lewy bodies. These conditions present with cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, and motor symptoms like rigidity. The absence of motor deficits and hallucinations in this patient makes alpha-synuclein an unlikely cause of her symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is characterized by neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau and amyloid-beta plaques. Hyperphosphorylated tau disrupts microtubule stability, impairing axonal transport and leading to synaptic dysfunction and neuronal death, particularly in the hippocampus and temporal lobes. These regions are crucial for memory and personality, explaining the patient's progressive memory loss and irritability. The extent of tau pathology correlates with cognitive decline, linking these biochemical changes to the clinical symptoms observed.

Key learning point: Progressive memory loss and personality changes in an elderly patient are characteristic of Alzheimer disease, a common form of dementia.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his wife due to memory lapses and personality changes over the past year. He forgets recent conversations and often asks the same questions repeatedly. He has become easily frustrated and sometimes accuses his wife of hiding his belongings. Neurological examination reveals no focal deficits. Laboratory tests, including vitamin B12 and TSH, are within normal limits (see report).
MRI of the brain: Diffuse cortical atrophy
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia is characterized by cognitive impairment with visual hallucinations, early parkinsonian signs, and fluctuations in attention. The absence of motor deficits or hallucinations, along with diffuse cortical atrophy on imaging, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Vascular dementia typically presents with stepwise cognitive decline and a history of cerebrovascular events or risk factors. It often involves focal neurological deficits and neuroimaging evidence of infarcts or white matter changes, not diffuse cortical atrophy. The gradual onset and absence of focal deficits in this patient are inconsistent with vascular dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal degeneration often presents with personality changes and occurs before age 65, with memory relatively preserved early on. The diffuse cortical atrophy and significant memory impairment in this patient do not align with the typical presentation of frontotemporal degeneration.

D) CORRECT:

Alzheimer disease manifests with progressive short-term memory loss, such as forgetting recent conversations and repetitive questioning, due to early involvement of the medial temporal lobes and hippocampus. Behavioral changes, including irritability and suspiciousness, occur as the disease affects cortical regions involved in personality. MRI findings of diffuse cortical atrophy reflect widespread neurodegeneration with beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Normal laboratory tests exclude reversible causes, supporting the diagnosis based on clinical and imaging findings.

Key learning point: Disturbed recent memory as a cardinal feature, along with behavioral changes, is most indicative of Alzheimer disease.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman with moderate-stage Alzheimer disease is in a care facility. Over the past two weeks, she has increasingly frequent episodes of agitation and paranoid delusions. She frequently accuses nursing staff of theft and becomes physically threatening. Structured activities and verbal redirection have had limited success. She has no history of severe adverse reactions to any medication. Vital signs are stable. Laboratory evaluations show no acute abnormalities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Donepezil, a cholinesterase inhibitor, primarily improves cognitive function in Alzheimer disease, not behavioral symptoms. Increasing its dose is unlikely to significantly improve agitation and psychotic features. Dose escalation may increase adverse effects, such as gastrointestinal disturbances and bradycardia, without addressing the acute need to manage behavioral risks.

B) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, can cause oversedation, increased fall risk, and paradoxical disinhibition in elderly patients with Alzheimer disease. Its as-needed use fails to provide consistent control over neuropsychiatric symptoms. The sedative and amnestic effects can exacerbate confusion and impair function, making it unsuitable for managing chronic behavioral disturbances in dementia.

C) CORRECT:

In moderate Alzheimer disease with severe agitation and paranoid delusions unresponsive to non-pharmacologic interventions, low-dose olanzapine is appropriate. Olanzapine, an atypical antipsychotic, antagonizes dopamine and serotonin receptors, reducing psychotic symptoms and calming aggressive behaviors. It is indicated when behavioral disturbances threaten safety and non-pharmacologic measures are insufficient. A low-dose minimizes adverse events like sedation and metabolic disturbances, crucial in the elderly. This approach aligns with guidelines for targeted pharmacotherapy in Alzheimer disease when non-medication strategies fail.

Key learning point: In patients with Alzheimer disease who present with agitation and psychotic symptoms unresponsive to non-pharmacological interventions, atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine are preferred due to a more favorable side effect profile compared to typical antipsychotics.

D) INCORRECT:

Valproate is primarily used for seizure disorders and mood stabilization in bipolar disorder. Its efficacy in managing agitation and psychotic features in Alzheimer disease lacks robust evidence. The elderly are particularly susceptible to valproate's side effects, such as sedation and increased fall risk, complicating the clinical picture when nonpharmacologic interventions are insufficient.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man presents with occasional difficulty recalling names of acquaintances and longer time to remember phone numbers. His family notes he manages his finances and daily activities without errors. He does not feel depressed or hopeless. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits, and he is oriented to time, place, and person. Serum chemistry, TSH, and vitamin B12 levels are normal. He is concerned about dementia but does not experience confusion or social withdrawal.
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his memory lapses?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Depression in older adults can mimic cognitive decline, but it typically involves mood disturbances like sadness or hopelessness, affecting daily functioning. This patient denies depressive symptoms and maintains independence in daily activities, making depression an unlikely cause of his memory lapses.

B) INCORRECT:

Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) involves objective cognitive deficits that exceed normal aging but do not impair daily functioning. This patient manages finances and daily activities without errors, and his clinical evaluation is normal. MCI typically involves more pronounced cognitive deficits evident on formal testing, which are not present here.

C) INCORRECT:

Early Alzheimer disease presents with memory impairment and progressively worsening deficits that interfere with daily functioning. This patient has occasional memory lapses but maintains intact daily activities and orientation. His neurological examination is unremarkable, reducing the likelihood of early Alzheimer disease.

D) CORRECT:

Age-related forgetfulness involves subtle memory changes as part of normal aging. This patient has occasional difficulty recalling names and numbers but maintains independence in daily activities and financial management. He shows no disorientation or language deficits, and his laboratory tests are normal. These factors, along with the absence of mood disturbances, suggest benign, age-associated memory lapses rather than a pathological process like mild cognitive impairment or neurodegenerative disorders.

Key learning point: Mild memory lapses in older adults, such as forgetting names or numbers, can be attributed to benign forgetfulness, which is a normal part of aging and not necessarily indicative of dementia.

He has increasing difficulty remembering names of acquaintances and now requires more assistance with dressing, cooking, and personal hygiene. He was diagnosed with a genetic disorder in infancy. On physical examination, he has prominent epicanthal folds, low-set small ears, and a protruding tongue. Mental status examination reveals significant deficits in both short- and long-term memory. Which one of the following neuropathologic changes is most likely responsible for his cognitive symptoms?

choices.text: Synaptic build-up of abnormal prion protein.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Synaptic build-up of abnormal prion protein causes prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is characterized by rapidly deteriorating cognitive function and myoclonus provoked by startle. Even though this patient has dementia, the protracted course of his illness favors another diagnosis. Moreover, trisomy 21 is not a risk factor for prion diseases.

B) CORRECT:

Accumulation of extracellular amyloid plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are observed in Alzheimer disease (AD). A majority of patients with trisomy 21 develop early-onset AD since an extra copy of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene (located on chromosome 21) leads to higher absolute levels of APP expression and deposition of the encoded amyloid-beta peptide in the brain as well as the cerebral vasculature. Mutations in the APP gene are associated with early-onset familial AD.

Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebral cortical tissue (H&E stain and anti-amyloid beta precursor protein immunostaining)

Multiple large red-brown extracellular structures are visible within the cortical matter. These are beta-amyloid plaques that have taken up the immunostain.

Accumulation of amyloid plaques in the interneuronal spaces of the brain is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Cytoplasmic inclusions of ubiquitinated TDP-43 are observed in one of the pathologic variants of the frontotemporal dementia (FTD) clinical spectrum, FTLD-TDP. FTD manifests in middle-aged individuals; however, unlike with this patient, memory and orientation are initially preserved and early symptoms include changes to personality and social behavior. Moreover, trisomy 21 is not a risk factor for FTD.

D) INCORRECT:

Intracellular aggregations of alpha-synuclein (Lewy bodies) are observed in Lewy body dementia and Parkinson disease; neither condition is associated with trisomy 21. Unlike this patient, who presents with early memory impairment, patients with Lewy body dementia show early impairment of attention, visuospatial, and executive functions. Moreover, Lewy body dementia is usually associated with other findings, such as visual hallucinations, movement disorders, dysautonomia, and sleep disorders.

E) INCORRECT:

Multifocal deposition of excess copper in the lentiform nucleus, liver, and other organs has been observed in Wilson disease, which is caused by impaired hepatocellular copper transport due to ATP7B gene mutation. Wilson disease typically manifests with liver disease, movement disorder, and psychiatric manifestations before the age of 35. None of these features are present in this patient.
questions.hint: Prominent epicanthal folds, low-set small ears, and a protruding tongue are signs of trisomy 21. This patient's presentation of cognitive and memory impairments is consistent with a condition that manifests early in patients with this genetic disorder.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the ED by police after being found wandering in her night dress near a grocery store. She is pleasant but disoriented to time and place. Her daughter arrives after an hour and reports a gradual decline in short-term memory over the past 2 years, though the patient has recently been eating poorly and sleeping erratically. She reports her mother has declined to go to see her primary care doctor about her memory problems, as she thinks it is normal to become mildly forgetful in old age. She has a history of treated hypothyroidism and mild hypertension. She takes levothyroxine and amlodipine. Vital signs are BP, 136/72 mm Hg; P, 82; R, 16; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F). Examination reveals no focal neurologic deficit, meningeal signs, or fever. A brief cognitive screening is performed, and her Mini–Mental State Examination (MMSE) score is 15/30. Point of care glucose is 98 mg/dL. Which combination of investigations is most appropriate for this patient’s initial ED evaluation?

choices.text: Complete blood count, thyroid-stimulating hormone, vitamin B12, serum electrolytes, and urinalysis
Complete blood count, inflammatory markers, lumbar puncture, and MRI brain
CT head with contrast, autoimmune encephalitis panel, and EEG
Vitamin B12, syphilis serology, thyroid function tests, erythrocyte sedimentation rate and lumbar puncture
Thyroid-stimulating hormone, complete blood count, serum electrolytes, lumbar puncture, and urinalysis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This combination appropriately screens for reversible metabolic and nutritional causes of cognitive impairment and helps rule out superimposed delirium from metabolic or infectious sources. The patient’s stable vital signs, normal glucose, absence of focal findings, and long-standing progressive memory decline are concerning for a major neurocognitive disorder (e.g., Alzheimer disease). Once acute causes are excluded in the ED, she should be referred to neurology for formal cognitive assessment and confirmation of the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

This combination investigates infectious or inflammatory causes of rapid cognitive decline. The absence of fever, meningismus, or acute neurologic findings makes these investigations inappropriate in a patient with long-standing, slowly progressive memory loss.

C) INCORRECT:

These studies are indicated for acute or subacute encephalopathy with seizures. In a stable, afebrile older adult with a 2 year-long course of cognitive decline, structural or autoimmune etiologies are unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

While vitamin B12 and thyroid function tests an appropriate part of the workup for reversible dementia, lumbar puncture, syphilis serology, and ESR are not indicated unless there is concern for CNS infection or vasculitis. Their inclusion here adds unnecessary testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Although thyroid testing, complete blood count, serum electrolytes, and urinalysis are appropriate, a lumbar puncture should be reserved for patients with suspected CNS infection or inflammation. In this case, the clinical course and exam are consistent with Alzheimer disease with possible mild delirium.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his daughter due to a 2-year history of progressive memory loss. His daughter reports he frequently misplaces items, repeats questions, and has gotten lost while driving in familiar neighborhoods. He recently received a notice for a late bill payment, which is uncharacteristic. He has a history of hypertension. On examination, his vital signs are normal. A neurologic examination shows no focal deficits. A cognitive screening test shows deficits in short-term recall and executive function. Laboratory studies for reversible causes of cognitive impairment are unremarkable. Which of the following imaging studies is most appropriate to further evaluate this patient's condition?

choices.text: CT of the head without contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The American Academy of Neurology recommends structural neuroimaging for all patients with a new diagnosis of dementia. The purpose is to exclude other causes of cognitive decline (e.g., tumor, subdural hematoma, normal pressure hydrocephalus, stroke) and to identify findings supportive of a specific diagnosis. MRI of the brain is the preferred modality due to its superior soft-tissue resolution, which allows for better detection of cerebrovascular disease, small tumors, and specific patterns of atrophy. For Alzheimer disease, MRI may show generalized and focal cortical atrophy, particularly medial temporal lobe atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

A single-photon emission computed tomography scan is a functional imaging study that measures regional cerebral blood flow. Similar to a positron emission tomography scan, it can help differentiate between dementia subtypes by identifying patterns of hypoperfusion. However, it is not part of the routine initial evaluation of a major neurocognitive disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

A noncontrast CT of the head can identify major structural abnormalities such as large tumors, chronic subdural hematomas, or evidence of significant strokes. It is a reasonable alternative when a different imaging modality is unavailable or contraindicated.

D) INCORRECT:

This study assesses for stenosis of the carotid arteries, which is a risk factor for ischemic stroke. Although this patient has hypertension, his clinical presentation is one of gradual, progressive cognitive decline rather than an acute neurologic event. His nonfocal neurologic examination also makes a recent, significant stroke less likely. This test evaluates the neck vasculature, not the brain parenchyma, and is not the primary imaging modality for a dementia workup.

E) INCORRECT:

A positron emission tomography scan with fluorodeoxyglucose is a functional imaging study that measures glucose metabolism in the brain. While it can show patterns characteristic of certain dementias, such as bilateral temporoparietal hypometabolism in Alzheimer disease, it is not a first-line diagnostic tool. It is typically reserved for cases in which the diagnosis is uncertain or for research purposes.
questions.hint: This patient's insidious onset of progressive memory and executive dysfunction is highly suggestive of Alzheimer disease.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents with a year of progressive memory impairment and behavioral changes. He often misplaces objects, forgets key details of recent conversations, and requires help managing finances. His father and paternal aunt died in their late 50s after a similar decline. He has no significant vascular risk factors. Neurologic examination shows slowed cognition, mild executive dysfunction, and difficulty performing learned motor tasks. Serum vitamin B12 and TSH are normal (see report).
CT of the head: Diffuse cortical atrophy
Which genetic abnormality is most likely responsible for his condition?

choices.text: CAG repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4
Mutation in the prion protein gene on chromosome 20
Missense mutation in the amyloid precursor protein gene on chromosome 21
Missense mutation in the microtubule-associated protein tau gene on chromosome 17

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CAG repeat expansion in the huntingtin gene causes Huntington disease, characterized by chorea, psychiatric disturbances, and caudate nucleus atrophy. The patient's symptoms of memory impairment and diffuse cortical atrophy do not align with Huntington disease, which typically presents with hyperkinetic movements and subcortical atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the prion protein gene (PRNP) cause familial prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, characterized by rapid cognitive decline, myoclonus, and cerebellar signs. The patient's gradual cognitive decline over a year and diffuse cortical atrophy are inconsistent with the rapid progression and specific MRI findings of prion diseases.

C) CORRECT:

The amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene on chromosome 21 is implicated in early-onset familial Alzheimer disease. Missense mutations in the APP gene alter its processing, leading to increased production of the aggregation-prone amyloid-β 42 (Aβ42) isoform. This results in extracellular amyloid plaque formation, a hallmark of Alzheimer disease. The patient's progressive memory impairment, behavioral changes, and family history of early-onset dementia align with this genetic abnormality. Additionally, individuals with trisomy 21 have an elevated risk of Alzheimer pathology due to an extra copy of the APP gene, which exacerbates Aβ production.

Key learning point: Mutations in the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene on chromosome 21 are associated with early-onset familial Alzheimer disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Missense mutations in the microtubule-associated protein tau (MAPT) gene are linked to frontotemporal dementia, presenting with behavioral changes and parkinsonian features. The patient's memory impairment and family history suggest familial Alzheimer disease rather than tau-associated frontotemporal dementia, which typically involves early personality changes and parkinsonism.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the physician by his father. Over the past year, the patient has become progressively forgetful and withdrawn. He frequently has trouble remembering names of acquaintances, and has been requiring increasing amounts of assistance with getting dressed, cooking, and personal hygiene. He was diagnosed with a genetic disorder during infancy. Physical examination shows prominent epicanthal folds, low-set small ears, and a protruding tongue. Mental examination shows significant deficits in short- and long-term memory. This patient's cognitive symptoms are most likely the result of which of the following neuropathologic changes?

choices.text: Synaptic build-up of abnormal prion protein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intracellular aggregations of alpha-synuclein (Lewy bodies) are observed in Lewy body dementia and Parkinson disease; neither condition is associated with trisomy 21. Unlike this patient, who presents with early memory impairment, patients with Lewy body dementia show early impairment of attention, visuospatial, and executive functions. Moreover, Lewy body dementia is usually associated with other findings, such as visual hallucinations, movement disorders, dysautonomia, and sleep disorders.
Image Description:

Microscopy of the substantia nigra of a patient with Parkinson disease (upper row: 60x magnification, lower row: 20x magnification; staining with antibodies against alpha-synuclein, counterstaining with Mayer hematoxylin)

Both Lewy bodies (spherical intracytoplasmic aggregates of alpha-synuclein; green overlay) and the strand-like Lewy neurites (neurites containing alpha-synuclein aggregates; white arrows) are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Multifocal deposition of excess copper in the lentiform nucleus, liver, and other organs has been observed in Wilson disease, which is caused by impaired hepatocellular copper transport due to ATP7B gene mutation. Wilson disease typically manifests with liver disease, movement disorder, and psychiatric manifestations before the age of 35. None of these features are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Synaptic build-up of abnormal prion protein causes prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, which is characterized by rapidly deteriorating cognitive function and myoclonus provoked by startle. Even though this patient has dementia, the protracted course of his illness favors another diagnosis. Moreover, trisomy 21 is not a risk factor for prion diseases.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cortical brain tissue (H&E stain)

The tissue shows spongiform degeneration, which is the result of neuronal loss and the formation of numerous vacuoles of varying size (green overlay).

This is the characteristic histopathological appearance of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (detection of prions is only possible via immunohistochemistry).

D) INCORRECT:

Cytoplasmic inclusions of ubiquitinated TDP-43 are observed in one of the pathologic variants of the frontotemporal dementia (FTD) clinical spectrum, FTLD-TDP. FTD manifests in middle-aged individuals; however, unlike with this patient, memory and orientation are initially preserved and early symptoms include changes to personality and social behavior. Moreover, trisomy 21 is not a risk factor for FTD.

E) CORRECT:

Accumulation of extracellular amyloid plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are observed in Alzheimer disease (AD). A majority of patients with trisomy 21 develop early-onset AD since an extra copy of the amyloid precursor protein (APP) gene (located on chromosome 21) leads to higher absolute levels of APP expression and deposition of the encoded amyloid-beta peptide in the brain as well as the cerebral vasculature. Mutations in the APP gene are associated with early-onset familial AD.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebral cortical tissue (H&E stain and anti-amyloid beta precursor protein immunostaining)

Multiple large red-brown extracellular structures are visible within the cortical matter. These are beta-amyloid plaques that have taken up the immunostain.

Accumulation of amyloid plaques in the interneuronal spaces of the brain is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease.
questions.hint: Prominent epicanthal folds, low-set small ears, and a protruding tongue are signs of trisomy 21. This patient's presentation of cognitive and memory impairments is consistent with a condition that manifests early in patients with this genetic disorder.
